gif 3048 58 487 ALTIMG CHNJC 60091 S1872-2067(24)60091-4 10.1016/S1872-2067(24)60091-4 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 XRD patterns of CeO2-T catalysts synthesized at various calcination temperatures. Fig. 2 SEM and TEM images of CeO2-400 (a,b), CeO2-500 (c,d), CeO2-600 (e,f), CeO2-700 (g,h) and CeO2-800 (i,j). Fig. 3 Raman spectra of CeO2-T catalysts. Fig. 4 XPS spectra of Ce 3d (a) and O 1s (b) of CeO2-T catalysts. Fig. 5 (a) NH3- and (b) CO2-TPD profiles of CeO2-T catalysts. Fig. 6 (a) Catalytic performance of CeO2-T catalysts for DMC synthesis in the absence of dehydrating agents. Reaction conditions: 0.1 g catalyst, 15 mL CH3OH, 120 °C, 3.0 MPa (initial pressure), 2 h. (b) Catalytic performance of CeO2-T catalysts for DMC synthesis in the presence of 2-CP. Reaction conditions: 0.1 g catalyst, 15 mL CH3OH, 50 mmol 2-CP, 120 °C, 3.0 MPa (initial pressure), 2 h. (c) Arrhenius plots of direct DMC synthesis in the absence and presence of 2-CP on CeO2-600. (d) Catalytic activity of CeO2-T catalysts for the hydrolysis of 2-CP. Reaction conditions: 0.01 g catalyst, 15 mL CH3OH, 30 mmol 2-CP, 30 mmol H2O, 120 °C, 3.0 MPa (initial pressure), 2 h. It should be noted that the interference of DMC synthesis reaction on the hydration process could be ignored since no trace amount of DMC was detected under above reaction conditions. Article Mechanism study on the influence of surface properties on the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate from CO2 and methanol over ceria catalysts Lei Dong a b Shengjie Zhu a b Yangyang Yuan a c * Xiaomin Zhang a Xiaowei Zhao a Yanping Chen a Lei Xu a * a National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c Hangzhou Institute of Advanced Studies, Zhejiang Normal University, Hangzhou 311231, Zhejiang, China Hangzhou Institute of Advanced Studies Zhejiang Normal University Hangzhou Zhejiang 311231 China Hangzhou Institute of Advanced Studies, Zhejiang Normal University, Hangzhou 311231, Zhejiang, China * Corresponding author The direct synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO2 and methanol has attracted much attention as an environmentally benign and alternative route for conventional routes. Herein, a series of cerium oxide catalysts with various textural features and surface properties were prepared by the one-pot synthesis method for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol, and the structure-performance relationship was investigated in detail. Characterization results revealed that both of surface acid-base properties and the oxygen vacancies contents decreased with the rising crystallinity at increasingly higher calcination temperature accompanied by an unexpectedly volcano-shaped trend of DMC yield observed on the catalysts. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) studies indicated that the adsorption rate of methanol is slower than that of CO2 and the methanol activation state largely influences the formation of key intermediate. Although the enhanced surface acidity-basicity and oxygen vacancies brought by low-temperature calcination could facilitate the activation of CO2, the presence of excess strongly basic sites on low-crystallinity sample was detrimental to DMC synthesis due to the preferred formation of unreactive mono/polydentate carbonates as well as the further impediment of methanol activation. Moreover, with the use of 2-cyanopyridine as a dehydration reagent, the DMC synthesis was found to be both influenced by the promotion from the rapid in situ removal of water and the inhibition from the competitive adsorption of hydration products on the same active sites. Graphical Abstract The balanced activation of reactants and the matching synergistic effect between the carboxylation and hydration reactions are essential for realizing efficient DMC synthesis. Keywords CeO2 Dimethyl carbonate Surface property Methanol activation 2-Cyanopyridine 1 Introduction The rapid development of industrialization and intensive consumption of fossil fuels in the past few decades have resulted in sharp increases of CO2 concentration in atmosphere. As a major component of greenhouse gases, the ever-increasing CO2 emissions provoked a series of severe ecological and environmental issues, such as global warming and ocean acidification [1,2]. Thus, the effective transformation of CO2 as an abundant and renewable carbon source to value-added chemicals is of great significance to alleviate greenhouse effect and facilitate the long-term sustainable development of chemical industry [3,4]. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is an important environmentally benign chemical due to its low-toxic, non-corrosive and biodegradable features [5]. The existence of diverse organic functional groups in the molecular structure makes it a green alternative for highly toxic reagents, such as phosgene and dimethyl sulfate in methylation and methoxycarbonylation reactions, and raw material for the production of multifunctional polymers [6,7]. Additionally, DMC is also applied as an electrolyte in lithium-ion batteries or a promising fuel additive to replace traditional methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) [8]. Among various synthetic approaches [5,8], the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol (Eq. (1)) is gaining increasing attention because of the environmentally friendly nature, high atom efficiency and avoidance of toxic substances [9]. In spite of potential economic and environmental advantages, there is still a long way from industrial application for this synthetic route due to the extremely low DMC yield resulting from the thermodynamic stability and chemical inertia of CO2 and severe equilibrium limitation () [10,11]. Therefore, the development of highly efficient catalysts for substrates activation and the exploitation of process intensification techniques are essential for the potential practical application of this synthetic route [12,13]. A variety of catalysts including bimetallic catalysts, ionic liquids and metal oxides have been reported for the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 [11,14–16], among which metal oxides have been intensively investigated due to the high catalytic activity and excellent selectivity. Mechanistic studies have revealed that thermodynamically stable CO2 can be adsorbed and activated on the oxygen vacancies that serve as Lewis acid sites [17], while methanol is activated to methyl species on acidic sites or methoxy species on basic sites of the catalysts [6,18–20], respectively. Thus, the surface acid-base properties of metal oxides play a crucial role in determining the catalytic performance. Song et al. [6,19] demonstrated a positive correlation between the amount of DMC produced and both the acidity and basicity of the catalyst over Ce-Zr solid solution catalysts, and they found that Ga2O3/Ce0.6Zr0.4O2 having the largest acidity and basicity exhibited the best catalytic performance. Gong et al. [21] investigated the effect of ceria morphologies on DMC synthesis and revealed that the spindle-like CeO2 with exposed (111) crystal facet presented the highest DMC yield owing to the most amount of acidic or basic sites. Moreover, the incorporation of Ti component to ceria [10] and iron species to zirconia [22] both evidenced that the improved surface acid-base properties could significantly facilitate the DMC synthesis. With the aim of overcoming the thermodynamic limitation of the reaction, the development of in situ water removal techniques is likewise of great importance. Compared with physical dehydration methods, such as the use of membrane reactors [23] and molecular sieves [24], the chemical dehydration methods take advantage of the great change in Gibbs free energy derived from the reaction of the dehydration reagents with H2O and supply a larger driving force for DMC synthesis [25]. It has been reported that the 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP) functioned as an efficient dehydration agent in the production of alkyl carbonates over ceria-based catalysts since its hydration process could be simultaneously catalyzed by ceria under the same reaction conditions as alkyl carbonates synthesis (Eq. (2)) [25–27]. Tomishige et al. [26] firstly reported the coupled reaction system consisting of carboxylation reaction of methanol with CO2 and hydration reaction of 2-CP, by which DMC yield was drastically improved from 0.3% to 94%. Urakawa et al. [28] successfully demonstrated the consecutive high-yield synthesis of DMC over CeO2 in a fixed-bed flow reactor and achieved excellent methanol conversion of > 95% and DMC selectivity of > 99% under optimal reaction conditions. Kinetic and theoretical study have revealed that water is likely to be dissociated on the oxygen defect site and the cooperativity of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites stabilize the intermediates in nitrile hydration [29,30]. Hitherto, despite that great efforts have been made to engineer surface functionalities of metal oxides to improve the catalytic activity and remarkable enhancement in DMC yield has been achieved through the use of dehydrants, the challenge still remains in terms of less understanding of specific influence of discrepancy in surface properties on the activation pathways of substrate molecules as well as the synergistic effect between the carboxylation and hydration processes in the coupled reaction system. In this work, a series of ceria catalysts were prepared by one-pot synthesis method and evaluated for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol. The physiochemical properties of catalysts were investigated by various characterization techniques detailedly. Intensive attention was paid to clarify the influence of surface acid-base properties and defect sites on the activation of substrate molecules and the formation of key intermediate. Moreover, in presence of 2-CP as a dehydration reagent, the potential double-edged effect brought by the hydration reaction of 2-CP on DMC synthesis was elucidated. Finally, a possible reaction mechanism for direct DMC synthesis over ceria catalysts was deduced from the above analysis and discussion. The results are helpful to understand the necessity of balanced surface properties in DMC synthesis and rational design of efficient catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.95%) and 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP, 98%) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Methanol (CH3OH, ≥ 99.9%) was obtained from Yuhe New Materials Co., Ltd (Shandong, China). CO2 with high purity (99.999%) was provided by Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics. All reagents were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Cerium oxide catalysts were prepared by conventional one-pot synthesis method [31]. Ce(NO3)3·6H2O precursor was calcinated in muffle furnace at 400, 500, 600, 700 and 800 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1, respectively. The obtained catalysts were denoted as CeO2-T, in which T stood for the corresponding calcination temperature. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) about the thermal stability of nitrate precursor was carried out on a Netzsch STA 449F3 analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from 40 to 800 °C under air atmosphere. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CeO2-T catalysts were measured by a PANalytical X'Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The scanning speed of 8°min−1 in the 2θ range of 10°–80° was adopted. The morphology of the catalysts was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL, JSM-7800F, 3.0 kV) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, JEM-2100, 200 kV). The textural properties of synthesized samples were determined by nitrogen isothermal adsorption/desorption on a Quadrasorb SI automated gas sorption analyzer at −196 °C. Prior to each measurement, the sample was outgassed at 300 °C for 6 h under vacuum to remove adsorbed water or other impurities. The specific surface areas were calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, and the pore size distributions were determined from the adsorption branch of isotherms using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. The total pore volumes were estimated from the N2 adsorption volume at relative pressure of 0.99. Raman spectra of the CeO2-T catalysts were collected on a Bruker Senterra Raman microscope connected with MultiRAM FT-Raman spectrometer in the range of 46–1540 cm−1 with 532 nm laser source and an output power of 2 mW. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab 250 spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) to investigate the chemical states of surface cerium and oxygen species. The measured binding energies were calibrated on the basis of C 1s peak at 284.8 eV in adventitious carbon concomitants. The acid-base properties of the catalysts were examined by temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD) on a Micrometrics Autochem 2920. Typically, 100 mg of the sample (40–60 mesh) was loaded into U-shaped quartz tube and pretreated at 400 °C for 90 min under He flow with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1. After cooling down to the target temperature, the sample was saturated with 8% NH3/He at 100 °C or pure CO2 at 50 °C at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 for 30 min followed by He puring (30 mL min−1) for another 30 min to remove the physisorbed NH3 or CO2. Thereafter, the desorption process was conducted from 100 or 50 to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under 30 mL min−1 of He stream and the desorbed signals of NH3 or CO2 were monitored by a TCD detector. In case of CO2-TPD, a cold trap filled with mixture of n-octane and liquid nitrogen (–57 °C) was installed to avoid the potential disturbance from H2O produced by the decomposition of surface carbonates. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 spectrometer by averaging 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1 in attenuated total reflection (ATR) mode. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements were performed on a PerkinElmer Frontier FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector and a Harrick in situ diffuse reflectance cell. The spectra were collected by averaging 16 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to tests, the catalysts were pretreated at 200 °C under Ar flow (30 mL min−1) for 1 h and then cooled down to the reaction temperature. The adsorption of CO2 or methanol was carried out by introducing high-purity CO2 gas flow (30 mL min−1) or Ar stream (15 mL min−1) saturated with methanol vapor into the reaction cell, respectively. The catalysts pre-adsorbed with CO2 (or methanol) were subsequently purged with Ar (15 mL min−1) for 20 min and then treated with methanol vapor (or CO2) to investigate the chemical interactions between methanol and pre-activated CO2 molecules (or between CO2 and activated methanol molecules) on the catalyst surfaces. It should be noted that all the spectra presented were difference spectra obtained from subtracting the background spectrum recorded at reaction temperature after pretreatment except for special illustration. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic evaluation for the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol was carried out in a 100-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave reactor with magnetic stirring. In a typical experiment, 0.1 g of catalyst and 15 mL of methanol were loaded into the reactor, and then purged with CO2 for five times to remove the residual air inside the autoclave. Afterwards, the reactor was pressurized with CO2 to 3.0 MPa and heated to 120 °C. After being kept stirred at 120 °C for 2 h, the reaction was stopped, and the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature in ice water bath and fully depressurized. N-propanol as an internal standard substance was added to the liquid mixture for the quantitative analysis. The products were analyzed by a gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A) equipped with a CP-WAX capillary column (25 m × 0.32 mm × 1.2 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The DMC selectivity in this reaction system was considered to be 100% since no other products were detected. The methanol conversion (X CH3OH) and the space-time yield of DMC (STY DMC) were calculated using the following equations (Eqs. (3) and (4)): (3) X CH 3 OH ( % ) = The amount of DMC produced ( mmol ) × 2 The initial amount of CH 3 OH ( mmol ) × 100 % (4) S T Y DMC ( mmol h - 1 g cat - 1 ) = The amount of DMC produced ( mmol ) The mass of catalyst ( g ) × Reaction time ( h ) × 100 % In the case of DMC synthesis in the presence of 2-CP, the experimental procedures were almost the same as that mentioned above except that an extra 50 mmol of 2-CP was added into the reactor in the initial stage and 20 mL of ethanol as a solvent was added to the liquid phase after reaction to ensure the complete dissolution of hydration products (2-picolinamide, 2-PA) in the mixture. At this time, the X CH3OH was calculated as Eq. (5): (5) The amount of DMC produced ( mmol ) × 2 + X CH 3 OH ( % ) = The amount of CH 3 OH converted to byproducts ( mmol ) The initial amount of CH 3 OH ( mmol ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterizations Thermogravimetric analysis was performed to investigate the thermal behaviour of cerium nitrate hexahydrate precursor during calcination process and the result is shown in Fig. S1. Three distinct weight loss stages could be observed in TG curve, which were located in the temperature range of 40–172, 172–236 and 236–590 °C, respectively. The first stage was attributed to the loss of three weakly bound crystal water molecules, in which Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was decomposed into Ce(NO3)3·3H2O and the weight loss was measured to be 12.66 wt%, close to the theoretical value of 12.45 wt%. Similarly, the second stage corresponded to the release of the remaining three water molecules with approximate weight loss of 12.64 wt%, resulting in the formation of Ce(NO3)3. The sharp decrease in the third stage was ascribed to the drastic decomposition of Ce(NO3)3 to cerium dioxide accompanied by the release of nitrogen oxides, where the observed weight loss percentage of 34.62 wt% approached the theoretical value of 35.47 wt%. Notably, the weight loss beyond 400 °C was almost negligible, indicating that the elemental composition of the products gradually stabilizes and the evolution of surface species and bulk phase structure mainly contributes to the thermal behaviour in this period. The crystalline structures of synthesized catalysts were characterized by XRD and the patterns are shown in Fig. 1 . The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.4° and 59.1° were identified for all samples, which corresponded to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) crystal facets of face-centered cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS 00-43-1002) [32], respectively. The intensities of diffraction peaks significantly increased with the rising calcination temperature, indicating that high-temperature thermal treatment is conducive to the improvement of the crystal structure and crystallinity of the synthesized samples. Besides, the mean crystalline size estimated by Scherrer equation using the (111) diffraction peak exhibited an obvious increasing trend with temperature (Table 1 ) due to the sintering of catalyst particles at elevated temperatures. The morphology and structural characteristics of CeO2-T catalysts were investigated by SEM and TEM, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . The SEM images demonstrated that the CeO2-T (T = 400, 500, 600, 700 °C) exhibited irregular fluffy morphologies with abundant pore structures and indistinct lamellar stacking structures, favoring for the exposure of active sites and the contact with substrate molecules, while CeO2-800 showed the morphology of densely packed nanoparticles, indicating the severe collapse of pore structures and agglomeration of catalyst nanocrystals at high calcination temperature. Moreover, a large number of discontinuous bright spots were observed on the surface of CeO2-400, which were reported to be crystal defects within the structure [33,34]. It was worthy to note that the amount of these defects decreased obviously as the synthesis temperature increased from 400 to 800 °C, implying the progressive perfection of ceria lattice structure under high-temperature treatment, which was consistent with stronger diffraction peak intensity and higher crystallinity manifested by Fig. 1. The high-resolution TEM images (HRTEM) in Fig. S2 revealed that the (111) crystal facets with interplanar distance of 0.31 nm dominated the catalysts surfaces, which were considered to be potential active planes for the DMC synthesis [21,35], accompanied by the appearance of (200) planes with spacing of 0.28 nm. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions of ceria synthesized at various temperatures are depicted in Fig. S3. All samples manifested the type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loop at relative pressure range of 0.6 to 0.9, revealing the presence of mesopores. Notably, the H3 type hysteresis loop observed on CeO2-400, CeO2-500, CeO2-600 and CeO2-700 proved the existence of slit-like pores while the insignificant loop of CeO2-800 was mainly contributed by the intergranular mesopores formed by stacking of catalyst nanoparticles as confirmed by SEM results. As shown in Fig. S3(b), the pore size distribution of CeO2-T (T = 400, 500, 600 and 700 °C) exhibited a hierarchically bimodal mode [36], comprising a minor peak centered at 2.4 nm and a major peak centered at 17.6 nm, but the CeO2-800 only displayed a weak broad peak around 40 nm. In terms of textural properties listed in Table 1, it was found that the specific surface areas and pore volumes of CeO2-T catalysts decreased remarkably with the rising calcination temperature, which could be explained by the evolution of the loosely packed flakelet structures to the densely agglomerated nanoparticles as exhibited in SEM and TEM images. The visible Raman spectra were conducted to investigate the defects in the catalysts structures and the result is presented in Fig. 3 . A distinctly strong peak at 462–464 cm−1 attributed to symmetric F2g vibration mode of ceria cubic fluorite structure was observed for all catalysts [37,38]. In the meantime, three weak peaks existed at 254, 595 and 1170 cm−1, which were the characteristics of a second-order transverse acoustic (2TA) mode, a defect-induced (D) mode and a second-order longitudinal optical (2LO) mode [36,39,40], respectively. The intensity ratio of the peak at 595 cm−1 to that of F2g was calculated to evaluate the relative concentrations of defects in the oxides [17,41]. As shown in Fig. S4, the I D/I F2g values of the CeO2-T catalysts were relatively low and decreased significantly in order of CeO2-400 > CeO2-500 > CeO2-600 > CeO2-700 > CeO2-800, suggesting that high calcination temperature greatly inhibits the formation of structural defects, such as oxygen vacancies, and relieves the lattice disorder in CeO2 fluorite structure. Furthermore, it was worthwhile to note that the Raman peak of F2g mode was blue shifted and narrowed with increasing calcination temperature (shown in inset in Fig. 3), which could be separately explained by the shrinkage of ceria lattice constant caused by diminishing oxygen vacancies and enlarged catalyst grain size due to agglomeration at higher temperature [42,43], being consistent with the results observed by XRD and TEM analysis. XPS measurements were carried out to investigate the chemical states and local environments of surface Ce and O species. The Ce 3d XPS spectra of CeO2-T catalysts are presented in Fig. 4(a) , which could be resolved into ten peaks labelled as V and U, corresponding to the spin-orbit splitting of Ce 3d 5/2 and Ce 3d 3/2, respectively [44]. Typically, the six peaks labelled as U′′′ (916.3 eV), U′′ (907.2 eV), U (900.5 eV), V′′′ (897.9 eV), V′′ (888.3 eV) and V (882.0 eV) were attributed to Ce4+, while the remaining U′ (902.1 eV), U0 (898.0 eV), V′ (883.8 eV) and V0 (880.4 eV) peaks were ascribed to Ce3+ [45]. The relative surface concentration of Ce3+ species could be calculated through the relation of Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) based on the integrated peak areas of Ce3+ and Ce4+ species. As shown in Table 1, the CeO2-400 exhibited the highest surface content of Ce3+ (29.6%) and the value decreased significantly with increasing calcination temperature. It has been reported that the presence of Ce3+ cations is closely related to the oxygen vacancies due to the requirement of electrical neutrality: 2Ce4+ + O2− → 2Ce3+ + 1/2O2 + □, in which □ represents a vacancy site [46,47]. Fig. 4(b) shows the O 1s spectra of CeO2-T catalysts. Three types of surface oxygen species were identified at binding energies of 529.3, 531.3 and 532.8 eV, attributed to the lattice oxygen (OL), the oxygen species adjacent to oxygen vacancies (OV) and other weakly chemisorbed oxygen species (OC) [34,40], respectively. The surface content of OV was estimated by peak area ratios through the OV/(OL + OV + OC) equation. As listed in Table 1, the surface OV densities ranked in the identical sequence with that of Ce3+ concentrations and CeO2-400 with highest surface Ce3+ content likewise possessed the highest concentration of surface oxygen vacancies, indicating a high oxygen mobility and favourable migration of oxygen species on the surface [36]. The decrease of vacancies sites could be ascribed to the attenuated surface roughness of the catalysts with higher crystallinity synthesized at elevated temperatures, reducing the number of structural defects on the surfaces [48,49]. The surface acid-base properties of catalysts are demonstrated to be the key factor in determining the catalytic performance for DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol [19,50]. Meanwhile, the metal oxides-catalyzed nitriles hydration also depends on the Lewis acid-base interactions between the substrates and surface coordinatively unsaturated metal cations and lattice oxygen anions [29,30,51]. Thus, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were conducted to investigate the effect of calcination temperature on the surface acidity and basicity of CeO2-T catalysts in detail, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . Generally, the desorption peaks of NH3 or CO2 located in the temperature range of < 200, 200–400 and > 400 °C are assigned to the weakly, moderately and strongly acidic or basic sites [44], respectively. Based on this, the amount of NH3 or CO2 desorbed from these acidic or basic sites with varying strength are calculated and listed in Table 2 . It could be observed that the adsorption amount of NH3 and CO2 with different strength both descended with increasing calcination temperature. CeO2-400 exhibited both the highest adsorption capacity of NH3 and CO2 of 477.6 and 361.8 μmol g−1, respectively. Given the aforementioned discussion on the textural properties and surface defective sites, the decrease in acidity and basicity could be explained by the following two aspects. Firstly, the destruction of pore structures induced by high-temperature calcination led to the sharp decrease in the specific surface areas and pore volumes of the catalysts, thereby reducing the exposure of surface active sites. Furthermore, the increase in the catalyst crystallinity resulting from the suppressed introduction of structural defects during nanostructure formation under high-temperature treatment inhibited the creation of oxygen vacancies and generated less coordinatively unsaturated metal cations or oxygen anions sites. These low coordinated M n+ cations and O2− anions exposed on the surface were believed to be the intrinsic source of acid-base properties of CeO2, where the coordinatively unsaturated Ce4+, Ce3+ species or oxygen vacancies with electron-accepting properties acted as the Lewis acid sites while the neighbouring electron-rich oxygen anions served as the Lewis base sites [52–55]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of ceria catalysts in direct DMC synthesis was investigated and the result is presented in Fig. 6(a) . The space-time yield of DMC increased first and then decreased with elevated preparation temperature, reaching the maximum value of 1.93 mmol g−1 h−1 on CeO2-500. According to previously proposed reaction mechanism, the formation of DMC is closely related to the surface acid-base properties or oxygen vacancies of metal oxides [6,15,18,19]. Generally, CO2 was adsorbed and activated on the basic sites or oxygen vacancies through Lewis acid-base interactions to form carbonates species with various adsorption configurations while methanol molecules were activated to produce methyl or methoxy species on the acidic or basic sites, respectively, among which the reactive species further reacted to generate DMC product. However, combined with the above characterizations that acidic or basicity density as well as oxygen vacancies all decreased with calcination temperature, the catalytic activity of CeO2-400 was unexpectedly quite lower compared with that of CeO2-500 and CeO2-600. The inconsistency of variation trends between the catalytic activity and the acid-base properties of the catalysts indicated that excess acidic or basic sites may impose a detrimental effect on the reaction. The methanol conversion was quite low owing to the severe thermodynamic limitation. In situ removal of water with chemical dehydrating agents has been demonstrated as an effective method to improve the conversion efficiency, among which 2-CP is the most efficient one because the hydration process of 2-CP could be catalytically promoted by cerium oxide at mild conditions. Herein, the catalytic performance of catalysts with 2-CP as a dehydrating agent was further investigated and the results are displayed in Fig. 6(b) and Fig. S5. The DMC yield increased remarkably in the presence of 2-CP and a nearly 10-fold increase was also obtained even on the inferior CeO2-800 (Fig. S5). It was worth noting that the CeO2-600 exhibited the highest value of 89.95 mmol g−1 h−1 followed by the order of CeO2-500 > CeO2-700 > CeO2-400 > CeO2-800, which was inconsistent with the variation trend presented in Fig. 6(a). The results indicated that the involvement of hydration process could greatly alter DMC formation rate, and the degree of improvement was closely related to the intrinsic properties of catalysts, which was less studied in the previous reports [12,26,56]. Preliminary kinetic studies manifested that the apparent activation energies of DMC synthesis in the absence and presence of 2-CP were calculated to be 75.4 and 76.0 kJ mol−1 over CeO2-600 catalyst (Fig. 6(c), Fig. S6 and Fig. S7), respectively. The approximate activation energy values before and after the addition of 2-CP indicated that the synthesis pathway of DMC could be reckoned to be unchanged in the ‘CeO2 + 2-CP’ system. Considering that the reactions of methanol carboxylation and 2-CP hydrolysis are both catalyzed by active sites on CeO2, unravelling the underlying mechanism for the activity alteration in ‘CeO2 + 2-CP’ system is of great importance to illustrate the potentially matching or competitive effect between the two reaction processes over metal oxides. Prior to this, the potential key factors determining the catalytic activity of carboxylation and hydration reactions were separately investigated. 3.3 Mechanism study 3.3.1 Mechanism insights into DMC synthesis in the absence of dehydrating agents Fig. 7(a) illustrates the relationship among the catalyst activity, CO2 adsorption amount and the surface concentration of oxygen vacancies. It could be seen that the increased surface content of OV promoted the adsorption of CO2, which was in turn conducive to the formation of DMC since the Lewis acid-base interaction between the nonbonding electron pairs of an oxygen atom from the CO2 molecule and the defective site likewise facilitated the activation of CO2 [57,58]. However, an unexpectedly sharp decrease in DMC yield was observed when surface OV content exceeded 18.0%. In view of the Lewis acidic nature of oxygen vacancies, similar result was also obtained in Fig. 7(b), in which the DMC yield increased initially and then decreased sharply with the increase of total acidity and basicity. A few researches have previously mentioned that the presence of strongly acidic or basic sites was unfavorable for the DMC synthesis possibly due to the difficult desorption of the product or the occurrence of side reactions [48,59,60]. In this study, these sites were also likely to give rise to the appearance of the truing point in activity change over CeO2-T catalysts. With the aim to gain further insight into the influence of discrepancy in acid-base properties on the activation pathways of substrate molecules and the formation of key active intermediates, in situ DRIFTS were carried out to investigate the structures of the adsorbed species and the functionalities of different active sites under simulated reaction conditions. Fig. S8 shows the evolution of DRIFTS spectra after CO2 adsorption on different ceria catalysts as a function of time. Upon exposure to CO2, the broad and highly overlapped bands rapidly emerged in the range of 1700–700 cm−1, mainly assigned to the chemisorbed surface carbonates with various configurations, accompanied by the appearance of intense bands between 2400 and 2200 cm−1 associated with the physisorbed CO2. As shown in Fig. 8(a) , the bands at around 1607, 1405 and 1214 cm−1 were characteristic of bicarbonates, usually resulting form the reaction between CO2 and basic surface hydroxyl groups [52]. The bands at 1642, 1244 cm−1 and the bands at 1584, 1289 cm−1 could be ascribed to bridged and bidentate carbonates, respectively, while the bands located in the 1509–1472 cm−1 together with the bands at 1381 and 1350 cm−1 belonged to monodentate and polydentate carbonates, which all rose from the interaction between CO2 and surface lattice oxygens or oxygen vacancies [52,61–63]. Notably, the formation of the same adsorbed species were observed on all ceria samples despite slight differences in the vibration frequencies and variations in relative intensity of IR signals. The DRIFTS spectra following methanol adsorption on ceria catalysts were collected and presented in Figs. S9 and 8(b). In the ν(OH) region, the emergence of the broad absorption feature in the range of 3500–3100 cm−1 (Fig. S9) was due to the newly formed physisorbed water or hydrogen-bonded OH groups after the dissociative adsorption of methanol, which likewise perturbed the IR features of hydroxyls with different coordinations between 3750 and 3600 cm−1 [64–66]. In the ν(CH) region, the pairs of bands at 2923 and 2827, 2912 and 2802 cm−1 (Fig. 8(b)) corresponded to the asymmetric and symmetric CH3 vibration modes of methoxy groups with different configurations while the bands at 2941 and 2844 cm−1 were attributed to the ν as(CH3) and ν s(CH3) modes of undissociated physisorbed methanol molecules on catalysts surfaces [65,67]. The band assigned to the overtone of CH3 bending vibration was also observed at 2868 cm−1 [68]. In the ν(CO) region, four distinct bands jointly grew at 1111, 1062, 1033 and 1015 cm−1, which were typically associated with the on-top methoxy (type I), doubly bridging-I methoxy (type II), doubly bridging-II methoxy (type II′) or physisorbed methanol and triply bridging methoxy (type III) species [68,69]. Notably, comparison of the temporal evolution of DRIFTS spectra in Figs. S8 and S9 indicates that the adsorption rate of methanol is clearly slower than that of CO2. Figs. 8(c) and 8(d) demonstrate the interactions of methanol with pre-adsorbed carbonates and CO2 with pre-adsorbed methoxy species, respectively, to investigate the reactivity and priority of substrate molecules to form intermediates, and the corresponding spectra evolution following the introduction of second component were displayed in Figs. S10 and S11. As shown in Figs. 8(d) and S11, upon the introduction of CO2, the emergence of the bands at 1593, 1464, 1341 and 1198 cm−1 were clearly observed, which were typical IR features of monomethyl carbonate (MMC) [70]. MMC was reckoned to be an important intermediate in the direct DMC synthesis, which could further react with the other methanol molecule to form the target product [50,66]. Meanwhile, the interaction between CO2 and methoxy species also led to a rapid decrease in the intensity of IR bands at 1111 and 1062 cm−1, implying that the consumed type I and II methoxy species are the active ones to take part in MMC formation [71]. However, in contrary to the significant IR signals in Fig. 8(d), there were barely characteristic peaks of MMC appearing in Fig. 8(c) after the exposure of adsorbed carbonates to methanol except a small IR band at 1593 cm−1, indicating that the reaction pathway for MMC synthesis through the reaction between methanol and carbonates is much more difficult than that between CO2 and methoxy groups [50], which suggests that the activation of methanol on catalysts surfaces is likely to play a key role in determining the catalytic performance. In view of the faster adsorption rate of CO2 and the nearly identical IR result during individual methanol adsorption process, it is believed that the distributions of surface carbonates with various adsorption strength preferentially adsorbed on catalysts surfaces make direct impact on the activation of methanol molecules, thereby influencing the formation of MMC intermediate and further DMC synthesis. According to studies about CO2 adsorption on metal oxides, the binding strength of various carbonates on oxides follows the order of polydentate carbonates > monodentate carbonates > bidentate carbonates > bridged carbonates > bicarbonates [52,72], among which only the bidentate carbonates are reported as active species to participate in MMC formation [17,61]. The deconvolution results of DRIFTS spectra in the ν(CO3) region after CO2 adsorption (Fig. S12 and Table 3 ) show that there existed a higher proportion of mono- and polydentate carbonates on CeO2-400 compared to the latter two samples, which generally arose from the strong interaction between CO2 and strongly basic sites [73] and displayed higher stability. Combined with unexpected activity drop observed on CeO2-400 and crucial role of activation state of methanol for MMC formation, this result suggests that although higher acidity-basicity and more oxygen vacancies deriving from lower crystallinity and more structural defects on CeO2-400 are conducive for the adsorption and activation of substrates theoretically, the higher percentage of unreactive mono- and polydentate carbonates formed on the excess strongly basic sites doesn't contribute to the formation of intermediates essentially, which in turn inhibits the effective activation of methanol and is detrimental to the DMC synthesis. 3.3.2 Mechanism discussion about 2-CP hydration on cerium dioxide In order to identify the effect of hydration process on DMC synthesis, the catalytic evaluation of CeO2-T catalysts for the hydration of 2-CP to 2-PA was also carried out and summarized in Fig. 6(d). It could be seen that the total space-time yield of 2-PA together with methyl picolinate, which was produced from the side reaction between the 2-PA and methanol, presented the same variation trend as that shown in Fig. 6(b). The highest hydration yield of 382 mmol g−1 h−1 was likewise achieved over CeO2-600 and the catalytic activity ranked in the identical sequence of CeO2-600 > CeO2-500 > CeO2-700 > CeO2-400 > CeO2-800 with the DMC yield in the coupling system, suggesting that the hydration process dominated and made a great influence on DMC synthesis in the coupled reaction system. According to previous literatures, the hydration of nitriles to amides likewise involves the concept of acid-base bifunctional catalysis, in which the metallic site or metal ions act as Lewis acidic sites to adsorb and activate –CN groups, and the lattice oxygen ions or surface active oxygen species serve as basic sites to generate nucleophilic hydroxyl species (OH δ−) from water molecules [51,74,75], the addition of which to carbon atoms of –CN groups is considered to be the rate-determining step in the hydration reaction [29,74]. In view of the above, in situ capping tests were performed to verify the potential roles of acidic and basic sites played in the hydration of 2-CP over cerium oxide. Pyridine with strong basicity and pyrrole with strong acidity were selected as shielding reagents [41,76] and added to the reaction mixture in the initial stage. Fig. S13 shows that in comparison to the slight fluctuation of hydration yield after the addition of pyridine, the existence of pyrrole remarkably restrained the hydration of 2-CP and the hydration yield decreased continuously with increasing pyrrole amount, indicating that the basic sites are requisite for hydration reaction, the blockage of which is likely to inhibit the dissociation of H2O to OH δ− species and further suppressed the rate-determining step. Moreover, it has been pointed out that the amides produced during nitriles hydration could also be adsorbed on ceria to form stable amide anion species through the interaction between both N and O atoms in amide groups and the surface cerium cations [77,78]. Consequently, the inferior catalytic performance of CeO2-400 or CeO2-500 for 2-CP hydration compared to CeO2-600 exhibited in Fig. 6(d) might arise from the higher adsorption amount of 2-PA on corresponding acidic sites, mainly the strong acidic sites [56], and thus weakens the accessibility of active sites to reactants due to the steric hinderance of hydration products, despite the fact that higher basicity on the former two samples is favourable for the reaction theoretically. 3.3.3 Mechanism analysis of DMC synthesis in the presence of 2-CP The concomitant 2-PA molecules adsorbed on the surface of cerium dioxide may also inhibit the activation of CO2 and methanol, further affecting the formation of DMC in ‘CeO2 + 2-CP’ system. Adsorption experiments with methanol or ‘methanol + 2-PA’ were conducted to investigate the adsorption states of amides over ceria catalysts. FT-IR spectra in Fig. S14 show that the broad and overlapped IR bands assigned to residual surface carbonates were clearly observed in the region of 1200–1700 cm−1 on the blank sample treated with only methanol. The addition of 2-PA to CeO2 resulted in the emergence of other distinct bands at 1049, 1306, 1394, 1566 and 1583 cm−1, corresponding to the δ ring, δ(CH), ν(C-N), δ(NH2) and ν ring vibration modes of 2-PA [78], respectively, corroborating the effective adsorption of 2-PA molecules on ceria catalysts surfaces. In order to determine the adsorption amounts of 2-PA on ceria catalysts quantitatively, the TG-DTG analysis of the catalysts after pre-adsorption treatments was also performed, and results are displayed in Fig. S15. It was worthwhile to note that compared to the sample pretreated with only methanol (Fig. S15(a)), the CeO2-400, CeO2-500, CeO2-600 and CeO2-700 pretreated with mixed solutions underwent an obvious weight loss stage in the temperature range between 170 and 400 °C, which was due to the oxidation of 2-PA on the catalyst surfaces [79,80]. Based on the weight loss data, the adsorption amounts of 2-PA were 26.9, 24.3, 19.3 and 10.9 mg gcat −1 on CeO2-400, 500, 600 and 700, respectively. According to previous reports, the adsorption of amide produced from the nitrile hydration was responsible for catalyst deactivation in the coupled reaction system [78,79]. However, in view of the much stronger adsorption strength of 2-PA, the influence of 2-PA should have occurred at the early stage of the reaction. Fig. 9(a) manifests the changes of catalytic activity in the presence of 2-PA under the same reaction conditions. It was found that the DMC yield decreased markedly after the addition of a certain amount of 2-PA, suggesting that the coadsorption of amides partially blocks the active sites for methanol or CO2 activation, thereby inhibiting the DMC synthesis. With the aim to identify the role of acidity or basicity in determining 2-PA adsorption with its consequent influence on DMC synthesis, the relationship between the ratio of surface acidity to basicity and the 2-PA adsorption amount or activity dropping degrees was further evaluated. As shown in Fig. 9(b), there existed clear positive correlations between the acidity/basicity ratio and the amide adsorption amount or the degree of activity inhibition, inferring that the competitive adsorption of 2-PA mainly occurs on the acidic sites and excess acidity makes the DMC synthesis susceptible to the shielding effect induced by 2-PA adsorption, thus influencing the matching degree between methanol carboxylation and 2-CP hydration reaction. Meanwhile, it was worth noting that further increase in 2-PA addition made slight influence on the DMC yield possibly due to the limited adsorption capacity on cerium oxide (Fig. S16). The reusability of CeO2-T catalysts for the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol was also carried out on the best-performing CeO2-600 catalyst. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed thoroughly with ethanol, dried at 80 °C for 12 h and further calcinated at 600 °C for 4 h or not. As can be seen in Fig. 10 , the DMC yield and methanol conversion continued to decrease in the consecutive running cycles when the recycled catalyst was only dried at 80 °C. On the contrary, the catalytic performance was well maintained on the reused catalyst treated with further high-temperature calcination during the continuous runs. As mentioned above, the adsorption of 2-PA species on the catalyst surface was found to be the main reason for the deactivation of CeO2 as verified by the appearance of characteristic IR bands related to 2-PA on the recollected catalyst without calcination (Fig. S17). The high-temperature treatment was an effective method to remove the adsorbed amides and refresh the active sites for the subsequent reaction. Based on above results, it could be summarized that the existence of 2-CP doesn't change the reaction mechanism essentially, however, the coexisting amides adsorbed on the catalysts surfaces during the concurrent hydrolysis process may hinder or occupy the active sites available for DMC synthesis, thus leading to the alteration of catalytic activity trend in the ‘CeO2 + 2-CP’ system compared to that in only CeO2 system. In the presence of 2-CP, the activity for DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol is essentially a synergetic result of the positively promoting effect stemming from the effective removal of water in reaction system and the negatively inhibiting effect resulting from the competitive adsorption of hydration products with substrates on the same active sites. 3.3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism for DMC synthesis in the absence or presence of 2-CP as a dehydrating agent On the basis of the characterization results discussed above and the previously reported literatures [17,50], the potential reaction mechanism for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol over CeO2-T catalysts is illustrated in Scheme 1 . Briefly, CO2 binds to basic surface hydroxyls, lattice oxygens or acidic oxygen vacancies and is activated to various surface carbonate species [52]. Concurrently, the activation of methanol occurs on the basic sites to produce methoxy groups or acidic sites to form methyl species [18,81]. Notably, the adsorption rate of methanol is clearly slower than that of CO2 and more susceptible to the pre-existing carbonate species with high adsorption strength. Afterwards, the reactive bidentate carbonates react with type I and II methoxy species to form MMC intermediate. Such intermediate could further react with adjacent methyl species to generate DMC, which is recognized as the rate-determining step in the whole catalytic process [12,17,61]. Apart from the mechanism illustration of reaction pathway for methanol carboxylation, the research also reveals the double-edged effect exerted on DMC synthesis by the addition of 2-CP. The hydration reaction is found to be more sensitive to changes in basicity in terms of inducing the dissociation of water molecules to generate OH δ− species and facilitating the subsequent nucleophilic attack of these species to cyan groups. Since the water co-produced during methanol adsorption is readily re-dissociated on catalyst surface to desorb methanol and lead to the hydrolysis of MMC intermediate [50,82], the remarkable dehydrating effect brought by 2-CP hydration could rapidly eliminate the associatively or dissociatively adsorbed water molecules on catalyst surface and contribute to DMC synthesis thermodynamically. On the other hand, there might exist a strong interaction between the amide groups and the acidic sites due to the basic nature of the corresponding hydration products, resulting in the strong adsorption of 2-PA species on catalyst surface. Thus, the firmly adsorbed amides and concomitant steric hinderance shield a considerable proportion of active sites essentially and weaken the activation of substrate molecules, restraining the formation of DMC reversely. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of CeO2 catalysts with varying microstructures and surface functionalities were prepared by the one-pot synthesis method and investigated as catalysts for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol. A volcano-shaped trend was observed for the DMC yield despite that increasing surface acidity-basicity and oxygen vacancies contents were obtained with descending calcination temperature and lower crystallinity. The effect of surface properties on the formation of key intermediates as well as the synergetic effect between the carboxylation and hydration processes in the coupled reaction system was thoroughly investigated. It's revealed that the adsorption and activation process of CO2 is facile than that of methanol and the methanol activation is more susceptible to the pre-existing carbonates formed on the catalyst surface, especially mono- and polydentate carbonate. Although the enhancement of acidity-basicity and oxygen vacancies deriving from low-temperature calcination could facilitate the activation of substrate molecules, the inactive mono- and polydentate carbonates with high stability formed on the excess strongly basic sites of the low-crystallinity ceria sample impedes the activation of methanol, which further inhibits the formation of MMC as well as DMC. Meanwhile, the preliminary studies on the hydration reaction of 2-CP indicated that despite the indispensable role of basic sites played in the hydrolysis process, the influence of acidic sites is significant since the strong chemical interaction existing between the acidic sites and the hydration products would lead to the strong adsorption of 2-PA on the catalyst surface, hindering the subsequent regeneration and utilization of adjacent active sites. Therefore, in the coupled reaction system of methanol carboxylation and 2-CP hydration, the DMC synthesis is not only prompted by the large forward driving force brought by the great change in Gibbs free energy after the addition of dehydration reagents, but also restrained by the blockage of active sites resulting from the competitive adsorption of hydration products. Herein, rational regulation of surface acidity and basicity with appropriate strength and quantities is of great significance to realize a good match between carboxylation and hydration reactions for high-yield production of DMC. coredata.dc:description: The direct synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO2 and methanol has attracted much attention as an environmentally benign and alternative route for conventional routes. Herein, a series of cerium oxide catalysts with various textural features and surface properties were prepared by the one-pot synthesis method for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol, and the structure-performance relationship was investigated in detail. Characterization results revealed that both of surface acid-base properties and the oxygen vacancies contents decreased with the rising crystallinity at increasingly higher calcination temperature accompanied by an unexpectedly volcano-shaped trend of DMC yield observed on the catalysts. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) studies indicated that the adsorption rate of methanol is slower than that of CO2 and the methanol activation state largely influences the formation of key intermediate. Although the enhanced surface acidity-basicity and oxygen vacancies brought by low-temperature calcination could facilitate the activation of CO2, the presence of excess strongly basic sites on low-crystallinity sample was detrimental to DMC synthesis due to the preferred formation of unreactive mono/polydentate carbonates as well as the further impediment of methanol activation. Moreover, with the use of 2-cyanopyridine as a dehydration reagent, the DMC synthesis was found to be both influenced by the promotion from the rapid in situ removal of water and the inhibition from the competitive adsorption of hydration products on the same active sites.
